reviewText: This show is very interesting.  You'll get to see how this obsession can get out of control.  It's unbelievable how some people live their lives among trash and animal waste.  You'll see how local clean-up crews, hoarding specialists, and family get involved in the process of cleaning out a house.The only things I have complaints about are the Text screens that come on the screen, telling you about hoarding.  You'll be reading the same definition of hoarding every single episode.  It gets very repetitive.  These text screens show up a lot, to the point where it feels you're staring at a black screen with text for most of the show.  Also, whenever they transition between the two hoarding stories, they play a high-pitched, spine tingling sound and it is very annoying........you'll see, just watch it.In one episode, an older woman spent two years living on a medical toilet, strapping herself in at night.  She had no running water, so she used adult diapers.  When she finished with one diaper, she would toss it over her head.  The diapers piled up in her kitchen, stacking taller than she was.  One night she fell out of her chair and was stuck in a pile of her own dirty diapers.

reviewText: I lived in a hoarding situation for 2 years, which may explain my fascination with this series.  Back in the early 80's, I handled the hoarder in all the wrong ways - endlessly trying to reason with him, yelling, sneaking things to the curb on garbage days, etc.  It was a toxic environment in more ways than one. I wish this series had been on back then so I would have known how to handle his emotional attachment to garbage and broken stuff.

reviewText: We get limited stuff on AFN (Armed Forces Network), so I really wanted to see what one of my coworkers was talking about.  I cannot believe that people live like this.  This DVD really opened my eyes to what goes on behind people's doors and in their heads.  I found this to be interesting a something to show my husband when he complains that I have too many articles of clothing.  I actually got rid of over 20 bags of clothes because of this show - I want to be nothing like these people.  I think it was well worth the price and this item got to me in just a little over a week.  I would buy from this seller again.
summary: Seeing is believing - and this is unbelievable!

reviewText: Hoarders: The Complete Season One7 Episodes on 2 Discs (2010)"Hoarders" on A&E; is probably the most compelling show you haven't seen. It is an absolutely fascinating in-depth look at people whose entire lives have been utterly consumed by clutter and possessions, most of which are absolute junk. The inability to part with any of these items as small as a soda can to as large as a broken-down School Bus means many of them are facing threats of eviction, divorce, having their children removed from them, or even going to jail for criminal littering. There are over three million people suffering from obsessive compulsive hoarding in the United States and each episode tells two of their stories.Hoarding is a psychological, painful disease where people are lost inside their own world with their stuff. Their stuff most of the time is more valuable to them than human relationships. In this show it can affect anyone as young as a seven year-old to as old as a woman in her seventies. These people are being asked to change by their landlords at threat of eviction, by their spouse or significant other on threat of leaving them, and for their own health and well-being as well as their families.These stories are amazing! A woman whose children had already been taken away from her was trying to clean up so they could be returned and she put her foot down at throwing out an old 7/11 Mountain Dew slurpee cup. One young man is suicidal and suffering panic attacks and is under the impression that if he removes the dog hair all over his apartment, that somehow that will make his dog die faster. The saddest story that brought tears to my eyes was that of a woman in her seventies who was blind in one eye who could not stop taking in stray cats. She wanted to badly to save them but as her house was cleaned, the amount of cat skeletons in her attic, garage, etc. was heartbreaking. They found around 70 cats total, 40 something of them alive. The most disgusting story was in the first episode of a woman who hoarded food and could not even recognize properly when it was rotten and assumed all food frozen was still good from several years earlier even when green and accused everyone around her of having poor stomachs. One older woman is addicted to yard sales and has so much junk in her house and yard that she has had to move into a hotel with her husband and can no longer afford that and is more devoted to her possessions than caring about having a relationship with her children.While all of their behaviors have gone into a downward spiral to the extreme, some have rational reasons for hoarding. One man believes collecting scrap metal in his yard is a valid way to save for his grandchildren's college funds some day. Many cannot bear to part with things that evoke certain memories, a gift someone gave them that they aren't using or their grown kids' baby clothes. Others are collectors of happy meal toys and stuffed animals believing some day they will sell them on Ebay -- but they won't. Depression-Era behaviors are passed down through generations making people prone to stocking up on items when they are on sale as if they'll never have that opportunity to purchase again and then they will forget they already have a bunch of it and continue to buy more until they are further into debt.Each person/couple is offered a crew that is able to clean-up their house in two days as well as the help of a professional organizer and/or therapist....if the hoarder is willing to let them. Each episode demonstrates who can rise above their disease and finish the clean-up and who allows their problems to swallow them up. It is so sad with all the help being offered when a person still can't let go.These pack-rats can get so absorbed that when put to the test to clean an area, they can spend the entire day or two in one bathroom or one corner of one room. The clean-up crew cannot act without the hoarders permission because just clean it up for them would allow the problem to begin all over again. The hoarder has to be involved in the process or the behavior will not change. The problem is that a hoarder's decision-making process is complex, slow, and emotional and it is very difficult to make progress. It is embarrassing and humiliating for them when the crew has to literally shovel up the debris and can find anything from animal droppings to human feces to mold or critter skeletons.There are two complaints about the series: the use of black screens with white text to give exposition between scenes to pick up the drama and let new people tuning it catch up feels like it slows down the story immensely and would be much more beneficial to have a narrator/voice over giving the information. Also the DVD Menu does not have a "Play All" option on the main menu, that option is on the Scene Menu. Why wouldn't you play all the scenes in an episode? That button seems misplaced and is annoying because every time you select a new episode you have to remember to hit "Play All".The series itself is interesting and absorbing from a psychological standpoint. I dare you to watch this and see if you end up cleaning your own house afterward.Bonus Features:There is additional unused footage of each of the stories that could not fit in the episode's time frame. There is more exploration into individual items they can't throw away and why. The series showed many successful decisions as well as failures for the hoarders and this shows more failures and lack of progress. A skunk was found in a dryer in one man's yard. One woman's children have a degenerative nerve disease unmentioned before that made it more difficult for them to walk around the house. Another woman's coupon collection could not be discarded because she said some places still accept expired coupons (from 2007).
summary: A fascinating look at a dabilitating disease that ruins lives, you cannot look away!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This show is my new "guilty pleasure." I sit & wonder what triggers this behavior? I realize that some hoarders are older, and having lived through the depression, they have the "nothing gets thrown out" mentality, but there are an equal number of younger people with this disease. We all become a slave to our possessions, but having to walk a narrow path from room to room, because things are piled up all over is a shame. I shudder when there are no sanitary facilities, and the person is forced to find other means for dealing with that. This is a real eye opening series, and it can be a bit shocking in parts.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nothing gets me motivated to declutter, clean, and organize my house faster than this show.  It is interesting, fascinating, inspiring, depressing, and disgusting all at the same time!  I feel sorry for most of the hoarders and merely disgusted with some.  I think this show is helping a lot of people improve their lives and will probably cause much prevention of hoarding in the next generation.  Who needs a book on clearing clutter and getting organized?  This show is sure to get you started and keep you going.

reviewText: I watched a few episodes and that was enough. It made me want to get up and clean my house (I'll bet I'm not the only one affected this way). The first time you see some of these hideously filthy, beyond-cluttered houses it's shocking. Then it's just repetitious and gross. I got through four episodes and threw in the towel. Point made. Enough.
summary: A little goes a long way.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One subject said he fears that throwing away his dog's shed hair would harm her.  An elderly woman said she'd rather be imprisoned than stop taking cats into her home.  From jump, you knoooooooow you are dealing with two real freaks!Years ago, one episode of "The Simpsons" showed a crazy, older lady who threw her hoarded cats at people.  This episode almost felt like life imitating art.  This lady's house had about 40 living cats and 30 cat corpses in it.  Through this episode I learned that cats will eat cat corpses.  I knew cats like to kill for fun (thus, their bad reputation in some cultures), but I didn't know about the cannibalism.Oftentimes, the subjects on this show face losing their homes, children, or freedom.  Jake, the man here, said he'd kill himself if his hoarding doesn't stop.  I would never laugh at such a serious topic, but I do note that his threatened punishment was self-imposed.  Jake cries often and I think many viewers would dismiss him as a crybaby.  His father is an aggressive drunk, but the episode makers never ask the father how he is able to accept his son as a rainbow-flag man.The partners in this episode are a trip too.  The woman's elderly husband has a hunched back.  I wonder if the hoarding helped to cause that.  He was sooooo passive.  On other episodes husbands threaten to leave if wives don't change, but this guy seemed like he wouldn't request a thing from anybody.  Jake has a hot boyfriend who supported him through it all.  Why is it that mentally-sound guys can't find good men, but disturbed Jake has one of the best ones!?This episode has Matt Paxton in it and I just love, love, love his pronounced chin dimple.  He could be Kirk Douglas' lost son!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a person without pay-tv, so being able to see this show is such a treat.  Almost anyone will tell you, watching this show makes you want to organize and clean your own house, at least that is how me and my friends see it.  I watched the whole season in a couple days and then did a thorough cleaning of my garage, then did a pre-Christmas selling trip to the swap meet, followed by the thrift store.  Now I am ready to order another season-- but to dismay, it appears that the only other episodes on DVD are Season two- Part One!! I'm hoping that more become available. I know I could watch it online probably, but I really don't like to watch things on the computer. Plus, this is a program I'll watch again & again, so it'd worth it to own it on dvd.

reviewText: I have noted how much the family reactions look IDENTICAL to the show that follows on cable: Intervention. I majored in abnormal psych, and I'm bizarrely fascinated by this mental illness. I sort of get it, it's directly pertaining to a loss. I used to have MANY books. They felt safe. I had them all over the place, but no food, or bugs.I am interested in the most recent episode I saw with a woman who would feed the dogs, and toss the can over her shoulder ONTO THE FLOOR! Ew. In those cases, sometimes I can't watch, because it's so painful to me to see the animals suffer so much.One episode, maybe not on this DVD set, had Glenn, whose beautiful young wife dies of a heart attack in her late 30s, apropos of nothing. He has three pet rats. Rats did what rats do, and he had to leave the house to them, which was then 2,700 plus animals. Yes, four rat digits! They were roaming free, but of course, while sweet, gentle, smart, extremely clean and durable pets, you can't TAME 2,700 animals, so two ended up dying/euthanized due to fighting over resources.It HAS to be more than three million  hoarders because I know TWO for a fact.Yes, I had a rat who was going to be food, so I saved the lab rat. They're very clean, they organize their food and waste. They don't smell. They ARE of course, nocturnal, on the down side. But you'd be unlikely to accidentally kill one if they can survive a five-story fall. Ferrets stink no matter what you do. Rats get big, mine was a hefty male two-hander, btw. Plus, finding a vet for them isn't easy even in a big, populated area. They made it look very easy on TV what with the rat rescue and all.It made me laugh when they ripped up walls and on the junction box for the electrics, where you can guide the wiring or make plugs/sockets out of it...they got into the wall, of course, and when they tore it open, you had six or seven tails hanging. All you saw were tails.But Dr. Zazio took three of the rats, and they adopted out the rest, which I was really charmed by. Even if, YES they are vermin in the house or property; if you get any ideas to adopt one; to use GLASS for their cages, ie, a fish tank, because they're not stupid, and CAN eat both concrete and steel. They are strong, too, and can get out of a VERY tiny space, and have no problems jumping, either. Three feet is easy for them.I LOVE this show, I LOVE how interesting it is how you can live in s***, and NOT notice it. Can't think of a more appropriate word, as poo doesn't cover it.I always go clean, too, BUT I don't find that a BAD thing. I have a lot of STUFF, just not JUNK. But I always feel better getting rid of stuff, and that's part of why I watch. The other part is my love for a happy ending, which you get 99 percent of the time here. I certainly NOTICE more areas I could be even cleaner after this show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Raional people wouldn't let this happen, but irrational people do.This show is a fascinating, must-see-tv programming that matters. It examines the mind sets of the people who hoard. It helps you to understand that what they see is treasure, what you see is trash.It's heart wrenching in places. Like the older woman who thought just because the food in her freezer wasn't puffy, it was still good. And the woman who lost her childern because of her hoarding, and by the end of the episode, she still couldn't part with her things to be allowed her family back.Some of these people are frustrating people. Like the man with long hair. He was admitting he needed to change. He knew he had a problem, but really didn't do anything about it until he was given a deadline and told to clean up or be evicted. he wasn't really a hoarder, so to speak, just an extremely messy person. Throwing used trash on his floor until it was knee deep. Not using the toilet, but the floor and trash instead, etc. The day of the clean up, he just sat at a desk!The human mind is a fascinating thing...and this show examines another viewpoint of the things people think and feel. Very educational.
summary: Compelling look at a facinating illness

reviewText: Having been a visiting nurse, and having been in the homes of many hoarders, it's fascinating to me to see a glimpse into the disorder that so affects each member of the family.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a fascinating TV series. I really liked watching how the mental health professionals interacted with the different "hoarders." A mother, about to lose her home due to problems that began with her hoarding issues, cried as she sorted through old baby clothes that had once belonged to her now-grown children. It was impossible not to sit there and cry with her. Unlike some other reality shows where the participants are freakish losers who we can compare ourselves to and feel superior (and normal by comparison), most of the people on Hoarders seem all too real and familiar.Just like in real life, there were a few hoarders who I had no sympathy for at all, but the vast majority of people on this TV show appeared to be reasonably normal people who got caught up in a mental compulsion beyond their control.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hoarders does show why these people do what they do.  Most don't want to do what they do.  Sadly, though, I watch this to get motivated to clean up my clutter.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hoarding causes horror and sickening problems that are beyond the scope of most so-called horror movies, because this is real life. Hoarding is a type of OCD, and the people who have it live in conditions that even the poorest people of the world would find unbearable.There are cat hoarders, food hoarders, scrap metal hoarders, trinket hoarders, magazine hoarders, and more.  Some accept help and some refuse it. All have serious emotional issues and problems that extend into their families and workplaces.  Even the city and county authorities get involved sometimes when the situation becomes so bad that lives and property values are endangered.It's upsetting, and yet it is hard not to watch.  And then you feel the urge to go and clean your house!
summary: horrifying and disgusting, but you can't stop watching
Title: N/A

reviewText: After five and a half hours - a full seven episodes - of this addicting reality show, you're likely to look around your own home and feel a little bit better about the clutter you may have. "Hoarders" - a reality show in the best sense of the term - features people (and sometimes couples) suffering from a debilitating compulsive disorder that prevents them from being able to part with pretty much anything. But these aren't just people who happen to have a lot of junk lying around, these are people on the verge of personal crisis - some are facing foreclosure, some are in danger of having their children taken away, some already have had their children taken away, and one especially incredible case features a man who is facing jail time unless he cleans up his property. Each case is unique and intriguing and though no two hoarders are the same, there's a clear throughline in the show - despite constant signs of distress and looming personal risks, these people are often unable to part with even the simplest objects.Each episode begins with a brief description of the disorder - which seems to include a mix of obsessive-compulsive disorder among other things - and covers two cases each, usually of hoarders with very different problems. For example, the finale includes a child who can't throw away even a single cotton ball on one hand and a grandfather with a few acres of scrap metal (including a full school bus!) on the other. The juxtaposition of the two cases in each episode keeps the show moving, especially as it becomes clear who will benefit from the assistance the crew on the show are offering and who will not. The show features a rotating crew of psychologists, moving crews, and professional organizers who show up at the designated hoarding houses and attempt to help the afflicted person(s) purge their houses. As often as not the attempts to help are unsuccessful, and though this can be frustrating as a viewer, it's also a testament to how intense the illness is. At the end of each episode there is a brief follow-up to say what the final outcome was of the intervention. These are especially interesting, though I often wished these bits were a bit more in-depth, particularly for those who had the most trouble letting go of anything.The 2-disc season one collection features a few minutes of extra footage from each episode, and once you've gotten through the show you'll be more than intrigued by what could have been filmed but left out. The series will soon be in its second season on A&E; and after sitting through the first season in a single sitting (maybe I have a bit of the obsessive-compulsive disorder myself!) I'm already ready for more. If you get a chance to check this show out, don't miss it. It could be called voyeuristic guilty pleasure reality television, but with featured psychologists giving their professional opinions, it feels like so much more.
summary: An incredibly addictive reality show! Worth owning (and hoarding)!
Title: N/A
